title: Martin Scorsese’s ‘The Irishman’: First Critic Reactions
text:
Photo: Netflix

Forgive us, Martin Scorsese, for we have sinned. The legendary director’s latest, The Irishman, had a lot of things stacked against it in the public’s eye: CGI de-aging, another Mob story, a rescinded wide release, and a 209-minute run time. After bolting to the bathroom, critics who attended a screening of the movie at the New York Film Festival tweeted their reactions to the epic, which stars Al Pacino, Robert De Niro, Joe Pesci, and Harvey Keitel. The dispatches confirm some things we already knew, like how Martin Scorsese is one talented SOB, it’s not GoodFellas, and that CGI de-aging is weird. But they’ve also revealed vital details, like the fact that Pacino eats a lot of ice cream and wears “incredible jammies.” Please, enjoy some spoiler-free reactions (notably not reviews!) to The Irishman and decide if it’s worth it to catch it in theaters on November 1 or wait for it to hit Netflix on November 27.

THE IRISHMAN is a quintessential Scorsese epic that moves easily over three and a half hours without dragging. To be able to maintain that kind of pacing in such a long film is the sign of a true master 🙌 — Tia Glista @ NYFF (@tiaelisabeth) September 27, 2019

Having now seen The Irishman, I can confirm that Martin Scorsese is good at making movies.



Also it doesn’t feel at all like 3.5 hours. — Adam Epstein (@aepstein) September 27, 2019

Al Pacino eats so much ice cream in THE IRISHMAN. five stars #NYFF57 — fran hoepfner (@franhoepfner) September 27, 2019

THE IRISHMAN is Marty’s old man movie! it’s about how you gotta have fifty conversations to do anything and everybody’s got an ego and it’s mostly just people chatting to each other and getting grumpy. terrific!! — David Sims (@davidlsims) September 27, 2019

also THE IRISHMAN joe pesci make me a salad challenge — karen han (@karenyhan) September 27, 2019

You don't feel THE IRISHMAN's 3.5-hour runtime. You do feel the grisly machinations of mob life, the momentum of some epic tracking shots, the mise en scene of 300 different restaurants, the gravity of Joe Pesci's face, and the agony a life's conscience served cold. — Emily Buder (@elbuder) September 27, 2019

the irishman is scorsese’s greatest hits album: a history of american violence filtered through a set of energetic, familiar performances. also, one of the tracks is remastered weirdly and just doesn’t feel right (i’m talking about robert de niro’s cgi face) — John DiLillo @ NYFF (@dilillicious) September 27, 2019

THE IRISHMAN: Pacino unhinges his jaw and swallows this thing whole like a python choking down a gazelle carcass, berserker mode king shit — Charles Bramesco (@intothecrevasse) September 27, 2019

THE IRISHMAN is not GOODFELLAS/CASINO part 3. Different pace different tone. It is, however, absolutely fucking fantastic and I am floored. All hail the King. — Jordan Hoffman (@jhoffman) September 27, 2019

THE IRISHMAN is like a greatest hits album from a master of the medium. Yes, that’s a positive.



The artifice of de-aging is more feature than bug.



It’s not “slow.” It often moves like lightening & elsewhere it’s downright Bressonian.



This is not a review! Those are embargoed. — erickohn (@erickohn) September 27, 2019
description: Critics at New York Film Festival react to Martin Scorsese’s mob epic ‘The Irishman’ starring Robert De Niro, Joe Pesci, and Al Pacino.
